sub_topic: Probability of a certain event occurring in a given time period
message_1: A bakery makes an average of 10 cakes per hour. If a customer arrives at the bakery and wants to buy a cake, what is the probability that the customer will have to wait 7 minutes or less for a cake to be available? Assume that the time between making cakes follows an exponential distribution with a mean of 6 minutes.
message_2:
Let X be the time between making cakes, which follows an exponential distribution with a mean of 6 minutes. The probability density function (pdf) of an exponential distribution is given by:

f(x) = (1/λ) * e^(-x/λ)

where λ is the mean of the distribution. In this case, λ = 6 minutes.

We want to find the probability that the customer will have to wait 7 minutes or less for a cake to be available, which is equivalent to finding the probability that X ≤ 7. To do this, we need to find the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the exponential distribution, which is given by:

F(x) = 1 - e^(-x/λ)

Now, we can find the probability that the customer will have to wait 7 minutes or less:

P(X ≤ 7) = F(7) = 1 - e^(-7/6)

P(X ≤ 7) ≈ 1 - e^(-1.1667) ≈ 1 - 0.3125 ≈ 0.6875

So, the probability that the customer will have to wait 7 minutes or less for a cake to be available is approximately 68.75%.
